[0] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/common/utils.py#L5029-L5031

I wonder if we could re-use some of the code in ContainerSharder._find_and_enable_shrinking_candidates to (a) do merge into broker and (b) also push out the changes so that shrinking might kick off sooner, rather than waiting for audit

I'm a little torn about that idea -- I rather like that this is currently an entirely off-line process. I want to be able to

* scp a busted DB to my local machine,
* run some manage commands on it to fix it,
* inspect it to make sure I've got everything the way I want it,
* then scp if back to an arbitrary handoff and let replication get it everywhere.

If/when I get to step 3 and things *aren't* how I expected, the roll-back plan is simple: delete my local copy. I can always grab a fresh copy and try again, which seems quite valuable.

The current shrinking code pushes the expanded acceptor shard range from the 'master' root to the shard containers...but I'm not sure if there is a recovery path if that initial push fails, so something like this change does seem necessary.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Are there other projects that use MD5 in non-security contexts besides swift and its clients, or is it just us?

Regardless, I'd hesitate to add a dependency on oslo.utils just for this, but rather just add the shim to swift/common/utils.py or something.

There are other projects that do (cinder and glance, for sure), but swift is by far, the most prolific use case.

I can certainly add the shim to swift/common/utils.py if that is preferred instead.  Let me know if thats what we'd like to do.

There are some useful comments on how best to implement this in the oslo review, so I'll wait for that to shake out.  I particularly like the idea of doing the check at load time.
encrypter.py, yeah? Even for the encryption middleware, md5 is only being used to preserve our ETag contract; that is to say, it's a glorified crc and not security-related.
Agreed.  I've had a couple of other security folks look at this and they've agreed.  I'll add those in the next patch set.

Updating the note on this based on comments with tburke.

While its probably better not to use md5 if you are trying to
protect user data, this usage is probably not really what fips cares about.  That is, obfuscation != crytography.  

And from the point of view of FIPs, this is probably a non-security context.

tburke did suggest failing when md5 is configured and FIPS is enabled - and suggested how the tests would be written in that case.  I can do that - or I can specify that this is a non-security context ..

What do we want to do?

swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3request..message: Why not switch to passing an pre-made instance instead of the class? Or, make unit tests pass md5_factory() that you already introduced.

Yeah, we only use this class with SHA256 -- if we need to make sure the content matches for a Content-MD5, we massage it into an ETag and let the object-server respond 422 (or, if reading some client request XML for processing, we make the comparison in check_md5 defined below).

I think I'd imagined that we might pass an md5 hasher in and simplify or entirely remove check_md5, but never quite got around to it.

I think you're asking me if we should change the signature of this class.  Not sure if I can answer that - I see that this class is used only once in this code base in this file -- and then to pass in sha256.  But I'm not sure if this class is exposed and instantiated by any other code.  Input from Christian/Tim?

swift/common/utils.py.message: Am I right to think that this function would bomb out here in FIPS mode?

It's not really a problem for it to bomb out here -- we've got some code around https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/obj/diskfile.py#L725-L735 to catch the IOError and fall back to something reasonable. As much as anything I wanted to make sure you were aware that we (may, depending on configuration) get an md5 hasher in this other way.
Thats very plausible.  I'll confirm when I run the functional tests.  This wasn't flagged before because bandit didn't detect this.  If it does bomb out, we'll address in a follow-on patch.

Do you view this as being materially different from what Swift does in hash_path() below? If so, in what ways? I just want to make sure I have a reasonable idea of when to feel comfortable setting usedforsecurity=False.

Up in __new__, I think we'd be justified in raising that "Unsupported hashing method: ..." error if you try to configure log anonymization with md5 and FIPS mode enabled. As for tests, I could see something like http://paste.openstack.org/show/798543/ being reasonable.

Tim, I'm going to defer to whatever you decide is the best behavior here.

While its probably better not to use md5 if you are trying to protect user data, this probably isn't really what fips cares about.  

That is, obfuscation != crytography.  So, in this case, it isn't materially different from what we do in hash_path.

From the point of view of FIPS, this is probably a non-security context.

This seems like a dangerous sort of a helper, as it moves the annotation of usedforsecurity=False away from the context we would need to judge whether that's true or not. I was going to ask if it would be better to just use

 defaultdict(lambda: md5(usedforsecurity=False))

in those couple places that would use this... but we've already found another place that it's useful... hmm...

I think I'd prefer to just skip this one assertion -- or even drop it all together. I very much prefer how this new shim raises a TypeError on unicode data over how py2 will "helpfully" try to encode it -- demonstrating the TypeErrors on py2 seems worthwhile.

I don't think (and I confirmed) the new shim raises a TypeError here in py2 either, and I think it shouldn't.

The shim is designed to do exactly what hashlib.md5 would do - except that it handles the extra keyword parameter.

If hashlib.md5 raises a TypeError on the data, then so should the shim.  If it doesn't, then the shim shouldn't either.

This test invokes the same call on both the shim and hashlib.md5 to confirm that the behavior is the same.

I think you're not devious enough here. You must also check that the actual MD5 digest of the source string matches what the hacked-up hashlib returned just now.

Also... Although setting class variables is a cute trick, I'd prefer this to be in setUp() in this case. Or at least the assertEqual(_md5_digest.hexdigest(), "0d6dc3c588ae71a04ce9a6beebbbba06") needs to be, I think.

Nice catch.

Actually, I think the problem here is that this test code is wrong.  I think I just need to do this to confirm that FIPS is enabled:

try:
    _md5_digest = hashlib.md5(_test_data).hexdigest()
    _fips_enabled = False
except ValueError:
    _fips_enabled = True

I changed the implementation a bit on the airship side of things here -
Basically before we were letting users specify the filenames for cloud-init userData and networkConfig. The file name only serves to instruct the container which file to read this data from. Given that any file name works, there is no need to have the user specify them, so the filenames I made as constants.
Instead, users can now use UserDataDoc and NetworkConfigDoc objects to specify the parameters of the documents that these values will be pulled from. Ex, if the user wants to use cloud-init user-data from a different source document, they can now do so.

distributedcloud/dcorch/common/config.py.message: A generic question, how subclouds are allocated among these workers to handle? Or how is the overall load allocated among these workers?

The current algorithm is any worker can handle any subcloud and actions for its associated endpoint types.  Each worker, with the subcloud sync_lock, checks for requests to handle or audit work so that only 1 worker handles the request/audit for the subcloud.

It is possible to in future allocate subcloud to specific workers based on the sync_obj mapping; this will also require handling of worker failure by rebalancing load, etc.

To clarify the initial sync or proxied request case the request is enqueued on request in database; and the worker engine checks based on the interval in sync_job_thread().

The sync_status update is immediate on initial sync or handling of proxied request or on audit cycle if not proxied.   The sync status is reported on any change in sync_status, such as on initial sync (from unknown), or when changing from out-of-sync to in-sync and vice-versa. 

This check is for robustness to ensure the sync status is reported if it hasnt been reported in some time.

neutron/agent/linux/keepalived.py.message: AFAIR with SIGKILL keepalived will not remove VIP address from gw device if it's master. This leads to a situation when same VIP is present on different nodes and hence to a long downtime (https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1851609). Need to make sure we're not introducing this bug here. Ideally need to figure out why keepalived is not exiting.

I tried the script and see how it works now, didn't know about separate monitoring process. Thanks for clarification! 
Maybe a warning log that process is not exiting with sigterm and going to be killed would be useful.

http://paste.openstack.org/show/801040/

Please take a look at this paste file. It contains a small script to built a small environment to run keepalived (not in containers), to configure and tested it.

keepalived spawns a monitoring thread to listen to the VRRP messages and provisioning the VIPs. 

If the monitoring thread is killed, the main process will spawn another one, start the voting process and provision again the VIPs. The VIPs are deleted from the interfaces **when the new thread is spawned**.

If the main thread is killed, the monitoring thread will remove the VIPs and exit.

The point of this patch is to kill the main thread and allow the monitoring thread to exit (deleting the VIPs). In any case, if both the main and the monitoring thread are blocked by any reason and the VIPs are not deleted, at least the main thread is removed and another instance can be spawn. That will initially delete the VIPs.

BTW, this is not related to the container issue you reported in the LP bug. When you stop the container, both threads are stopped and the monitoring thread cannot exit properly, deleting the VIPs.

specs/victoria/reset-state-robustificati.message:
Reset volume to "error_managing_deleting"?

Reset volume to "downloading"?

Reset backup to "restoring"?  (backup-reset-state)

If we add a --force flag, I'm afraid people will just use --force all the time.  If you have to switch tools, maybe you'll think twice about what you're doing?  On the other hand, you might simply just go directly to cinder-manage when you want to reset state, which wouldn't even give you the option of seeing the new, informative error messages.  It would be good to hear some more opinions about this.

As long as you don't provide an option to reset the state, people will 
a) file a bug to request such option
b) start mangling with the database.

I'd say: maybe better leave the option to do that with a nicer user interface than the mysql command or so. cinder-manager is probably fine.
